title: Lesson Learned on Gemini
text: Of Note

title: Lesson Learned on Gemini
text:
1. How Models Represent the World
Models are like maps or pictures—they represent something else. Philosophers usually divide them into two main types based on what they represent.

Models of Phenomena
These are models of things or events in the real world. * Examples: The Bohr model of the atom, a scale model of a bridge, or a computer model of the weather. * The Big Question: How does a model (which is just an object or an idea) represent a real phenomenon? It’s similar to asking how a painting represents a landscape.


Models of Data
Scientific data often comes from observations that are “messy.” There might be errors or irrelevant details. * What they do: A “model of data” is a cleaned-up version of that information. * Example: If you plot points on a graph and they are scattered, you might draw a smooth curve through them. That smooth curve is the model of the data. It helps scientists see the pattern rather than just the noise.


Different Styles of Models
Scientists use different styles to represent things, just like artists use different styles (like realism or abstract art).

Scale Models: These are just smaller (or larger) physical copies of the target.

Example: A wooden model of a car or a plastic model of a DNA molecule. They look like the real thing but might be made of different materials.

Idealized Models: These models simplify reality to make it easier to understand.

“Stripping Away” (Aristotelian): You ignore details that don’t matter for your problem. For example, when studying planetary orbits, you might treat a planet as a simple dot with mass, ignoring its mountains and oceans.
“Distorting” (Galilean): You imagine a world that physically cannot exist to test a theory. For example, imagining a surface with zero friction or a market where everyone knows everything.

Analogical Models: These use a familiar object to explain something new.

Example: Describing the nucleus of an atom as a “liquid drop.” It isn’t actually a drop of liquid, but it behaves like one in some ways.

title: Lesson Learned on Gemini
text:
2. What Are Models Made Of? (Ontology)
If you hold a model car, it’s made of wood or plastic. But what is a scientific model made of?

Physical Objects: Some are real material things, like the model of a bridge used in a wind tunnel.
Fictional Objects: Some philosophers argue that models are like characters in a book (like Sherlock Holmes). They don’t exist in the real world, but we can still study them and learn true things about them.
Math and Sets: Many scientists view models as mathematical structures (sets of equations and rules).
Descriptions: Some simply say a model is just a detailed description of a system.

title: Lesson Learned on Gemini
text:
3. Learning with Models (Epistemology)
We use models because we can’t always test the real world. We can’t easily crash real trains to test safety, so we use models. Learning happens in two steps:

Learning about the Model: We run experiments or simulations on the model itself. For example, we might run a computer program to see how a digital disease spreads.
Translating to Reality: We take what we learned from the model and apply it to the real world. If the model bridge collapses in the wind tunnel, we assume the real bridge might collapse in a real storm.

title: Lesson Learned on Gemini
text:
4. Models vs. Theories
Is a model the same thing as a theory? It’s a bit fuzzy, but here are two main views:

The Syntactic View: This is an older view that focuses on logic. It says a “theory” is a set of sentences or math equations, and a “model” is just a way to interpret those equations.
The Semantic View: This is the more modern view. It says that the theory is actually a collection of models. For example, “Classical Mechanics” isn’t just a list of rules; it’s the family of all the different models (pendulums, planetary orbits, billiard balls) that follow those rules.

title: Lesson Learned on Gemini
text:
5. Conclusion
Models are central to how modern science works. They are not just side-projects; they are the main instruments scientists use to represent the world, manipulate data, and formulate theories. Whether they are physical objects, complex equations, or imagined fictions, models help us grasp the complexity of the universe.


References & Further Reading

Original Article: Frigg, Roman and Hartmann, Stephan, “Models in Science”, The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Fall 2013 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.).
Reference on Representation: Van Fraassen, B. C. (1980). The Scientific Image. Oxford: Clarendon.
Reference on Data Models: Suppes, P. (1962). “Models of Data”.

title: Gemini on Models
text:
TL;DR
Gemini, from Google, is an extremely powerful AI tool. I will use it here to help me think about the use of models.



Claude Interactions








NotePrompt:




how are models used in academic disciplines? give an example or two of common models in at least 20 academic disciplines in a formatted table of markdown code with a linked reference for each model that provides more extensive detail and a column that includes whether the model is predictive or explanatory
This response is great except that I want you to provide the response in its entirety as markdown code, not rendered.



Models are the primary tools scholars use to bridge the gap between abstract theory and the complex reality of the world. In academic disciplines, a model is a simplified representation of a system, concept, or process.
Scholars use them for three primary purposes: 1. Explanation: To isolate specific variables and understand how or why a phenomenon occurs (e.g., how neurons fire). 2. Prediction: To forecast future states or unseen data based on current parameters (e.g., predicting the spread of a virus). 3. Simulation: To create “sandbox” environments where theoretical scenarios can be tested without real-world risk (e.g., economic crash simulations).
The following table outlines common models across 20 distinct academic disciplines.

Common Academic Models



Discipline
Model Name
Use/Description
Type
Reference




1. Physics
Standard Model
Explains the fundamental particles (quarks, leptons) and forces (strong, weak, electromagnetic) that constitute matter.
Explanatory & Predictive
CERN Source


2. Epidemiology
SIR Model
Mathematical model that tracks Susceptible, Infectious, and Recovered individuals to simulate disease spread.
Predictive
NIH Reference


3. Economics
IS-LM Model
Macroeconomic tool demonstrating the relationship between interest rates and the asset/goods market (Investment-Saving/Liquidity-Money).
Explanatory & Predictive
Investopedia Detail


4. Psychology
Big Five (OCEAN)
A taxonomy for personality traits: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.
Explanatory
NIH Reference


5. Biology
Lotka-Volterra
A pair of differential equations used to describe the dynamics of biological systems in which two species interact (Predator-Prey).
Predictive
Nature Scitable


6. Sociology
Gravity Model
Predicts the volume of interaction (migration, trade, communication) between two places based on their size and distance.
Predictive
ThoughtCo Overview


7. Neuroscience
Hodgkin-Huxley
A mathematical model describing how action potentials (electrical signals) in neurons are initiated and propagated.
Explanatory & Predictive
Scholarpedia


8. Pol. Science
Median Voter Theorem
Argues that in a majority-rule election system, candidates will converge to the position of the median voter to win.
Predictive
NBER Paper


9. Geography
Central Place Theory
Explains the number, size, and location of human settlements in a residential system.
Explanatory
WVU Research


10. Chemistry
VSEPR Theory
A model used to predict the geometry of individual molecules from the number of electron pairs surrounding their central atoms.
Predictive
Purdue Chemistry


11. Linguistics
Tree Model
A comparative model depicting the genealogical relationship between languages as they evolve from a common ancestor.
Explanatory
Language Files


12. Computer Sci
OSI Model
A conceptual framework that describes the functions of a networking system (7 layers) to ensure interoperability.
Explanatory (Conceptual)
Cloudflare Guide


13. Geology
Plate Tectonics
Describes the large-scale motion of seven large plates and the movements of a larger number of smaller plates of Earth’s lithosphere.
Explanatory
USGS Pubs


14. Anthropology
Recent African Origin
The dominant model of the geographic origin and early migration of anatomically modern humans (Out of Africa).
Explanatory
Smithsonian Human Origins


15. Philosophy
Trolley Problem
A “thought experiment” (conceptual model) used to explore ethical intuitions regarding utilitarianism and deontology.
Explanatory (Explorative)
Stanford Encyclopedia


16. Marketing
AIDA Model
Traces the customer journey through Awareness, Interest, Desire, and Action.
Explanatory (Process)
Oxford Reference


17. Management
SWOT Analysis
A strategic planning technique used to identify Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats.
Explanatory (Analytical)
Harvard Business School


18. Astronomy
Big Bang Model
The prevailing cosmological model for the observable universe from the earliest known periods through its subsequent large-scale evolution.
Explanatory & Predictive
NASA Science


19. Education
Bloom’s Taxonomy
A hierarchical model used to classify educational learning objectives into levels of complexity and specificity.
Explanatory (Structural)
Vanderbilt Teaching


20. Env. Science
GCM (Climate)
Global Circulation Models use math/physics to simulate the atmosphere and oceans to predict future climate change.
Predictive
NOAA Explanation





Would you like me to…
Generate a Python script or R code to simulate one of the simpler predictive models, such as the SIR Model or Lotka-Volterra, so you can see how the variables interact in real-time?

title: Gemini on Business Models
text: Gemini is powerful, and a few tidbits help a great deal; NotebookLM makes it even more powerful.

title: Gemini on Business Models
text:
The Utility of Business Models
Models serve three primary functions across all disciplines: 1. Simplification: They strip away noise to focus on key variables (e.g., price vs. demand).
2. Communication: They provide a shared language and visual structure for teams (e.g., a supply chain diagram).
3. Prediction and Decision Support: They allow for scenario planning and “what-if” analyses (e.g., financial forecasting).

title: Gemini on Business Models
text:
1. Strategic Management
Strategy models assist leaders in analyzing competitive environments and internal capabilities to define long-term goals.

Example A: Porter’s Five Forces
Overview: Developed by Michael Porter, this model analyzes the competitive intensity and attractiveness of an industry.
Components: 1. Threat of New Entrants: Barriers to entry (capital, regulation).
2. Bargaining Power of Suppliers: Concentration of suppliers, switching costs.
3. Bargaining Power of Buyers: Price sensitivity, volume of purchase.
4. Threat of Substitute Products: Alternative solutions meeting the same need.
5. Rivalry Among Existing Competitors: Number of competitors, industry growth.
Application: Used to determine whether to enter a new market or how to position a firm to defend against competitive forces.


Example B: SWOT Analysis
Overview: A foundational framework used to evaluate a company’s competitive position. Components:.
* Strengths (Internal): Unique assets, strong brand, proprietary tech.
* Weaknesses (Internal): Resource gaps, poor reputation, lack of capital.
* Opportunities (External): Emerging markets, changing regulations, tech advancements.
* Threats (External): New competitors, economic downturns, changing consumer behavior.
Application: Used during strategic planning retreats to align internal capabilities with external possibilities.

References: * Porter, M. E. (1979). “How Competitive Forces Shape Strategy”. Harvard Business Review. * Humphrey, A. (2005). “SWOT Analysis for Management Consulting”. SRI International.

title: Gemini on Business Models
text:
2. Marketing
Marketing models help firms understand customer behavior, segment populations, and optimize the value proposition.

Example A: The Marketing Mix (The 4 Ps)
Overview: A model to outline the key factors that determine a product’s offer.
Components:.
1. Product: Features, quality, branding, packaging.
2. Price: List price, discounts, payment terms.
3. Place: Distribution channels, logistics, market coverage.
4. Promotion: Advertising, sales force, public relations.
Application: Used to draft go-to-market strategies and ensure all aspects of the offering are aligned with the target audience.


Example B: STP Model (Segmentation, Targeting, Positioning)
Overview: A strategic approach that prioritizes the customer over the product.
Components:.
1. Segmentation: Dividing the market into distinct groups (demographic, psychographic).
2. Targeting: Selecting the most attractive segments to focus on.
3. Positioning: Creating a distinct image in the mind of the target audience compared to competitors.
Application: Essential for digital marketing campaigns to ensure ad spend is directed toward high-conversion audiences.

References: * McCarthy, E. J. (1960). Basic Marketing: A Managerial Approach. Irwin. * Kotler, P., & Keller, K. L. (2015). Marketing Management. Pearson.

title: Gemini on Business Models
text:
3. Finance and Accounting
Financial models are often mathematical, used to value assets, assess risk, and analyze performance.

Example A: CAPM (Capital Asset Pricing Model)
Overview: Describes the relationship between systematic risk and expected return for assets, particularly stocks.
Formula: \[E(R_i) = R_f + \beta_i (E(R_m) - R_f)\]

\(E(R_i)\): Expected return of investment.

\(R_f\): Risk-free rate.

\(\beta_i\): Beta (sensitivity of the asset to market movements).

\((E(R_m) - R_f)\): Market risk premium.
Application: Used in corporate finance to determine the cost of equity capital and to evaluate the performance of managed portfolios.



Example B: DuPont Analysis
Overview: A technique to decompose Return on Equity (ROE) to understand the drivers of financial performance.
Formula: \[ROE = \text{Profit Margin} \times \text{Asset Turnover} \times \text{Financial Leverage}\]

Profit Margin: Operational efficiency.

Asset Turnover: Asset use efficiency.

Financial Leverage: Use of debt.
Application: Used by financial analysts to pinpoint whether a company’s growth is driven by high margins, efficient asset use, or high debt loading.


References: * Sharpe, W. F. (1964). “Capital Asset Prices: A Theory of Market Equilibrium under Conditions of Risk”. Journal of Finance. * Soliman, M. T. (2008). “The Use of DuPont Analysis by Market Participants”. The Accounting Review.

title: Gemini on Business Models
text:
4. Operations and Supply Chain
Operations models focus on efficiency, quality control, and logistics optimization.

Example A: EOQ (Economic Order Quantity)
Overview: A formula that calculates the ideal order quantity a company should purchase to minimize inventory costs.
Formula: \[EOQ = \sqrt{\frac{2DS}{H}}\]

\(D\): Demand in units.

\(S\): Order cost (per order).

\(H\): Holding costs (per unit, per year).

Application: Used in inventory management to balance the cost of ordering stock against the cost of holding it.


Example B: Six Sigma DMAIC
Overview: A data-driven quality strategy for improving processes.
Phases:.
1. Define: The problem and project goals.
2. Measure: Current process performance.
3. Analyze: The root causes of defects.
4. Improve: The process by eliminating causes.
5. Control: Future process performance to ensure deviations don’t recur.
Application: Used in manufacturing and service industries to reduce defects and improve consistency.

References: * Harris, F. W. (1913). “How Many Parts to Make at Once”. Factory, The Magazine of Management. * Pyzdek, T., & Keller, P. A. (2014). The Six Sigma Handbook. McGraw-Hill Education.

title: Gemini on Business Models
text:
5. Human Resources (Organizational Behavior)
HR models attempt to quantify or structure the “soft skills” of motivation, leadership, and organizational structure.

Example A: Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs (Applied to Business)
Overview: A psychological theory arguing that humans have tiers of needs that must be met in order.
Tiers:.
1. Physiological: Salary, basic working conditions.
2. Safety: Job security, health insurance.
3. Social: Team culture, belonging.
4. Esteem: Job titles, recognition, awards.
5. Self-Actualization: Career growth, autonomy, creative work.
Application: Used to design compensation packages and employee engagement programs.


Example B: The HR Business Partner Model (Ulrich Model)
Overview: Defines how HR should be organized to deliver value.
Four Roles:.
1. Strategic Partner: Aligning HR with business strategy.
2. Change Agent: Managing transformation and culture.
3. Administrative Expert: Efficiently managing processes (payroll, benefits).
4. Employee Champion: Listening to and advocating for employees.
Application: Used to restructure HR departments to move away from purely administrative tasks toward strategic contribution.

References: * Maslow, A. H. (1943). “A Theory of Human Motivation”. Psychological Review. * Ulrich, D. (1996). Human Resource Champions. Harvard Business School Press.

It produces a variety of content.

NotePrompt:




how are models used in academic disciplines? give an example or two of common models in at least 20 academic disciplines in a markdown formatted list
could you provide this response as a bulleted list in markdown code with a linked reference for each such model that provides more detail?

title: Claude on Models
text:
Natural Sciences

Physics: The Standard Model describes fundamental particles and forces; Newton’s laws of motion model mechanical systems and predict object behavior under forces. Standard Model | Newton’s Laws
Chemistry: The Bohr model represents atomic structure with electrons in defined orbits; molecular orbital theory models chemical bonding and molecular properties. Bohr Model | Molecular Orbital Theory
Biology: The Hardy-Weinberg model predicts allele frequencies in populations; the logistic growth model describes population dynamics with carrying capacity constraints. Hardy-Weinberg | Logistic Growth
Astronomy: The Big Bang model explains cosmic origin and evolution; stellar evolution models predict how stars change over their lifetimes based on mass and composition. Big Bang | Stellar Evolution
Geology: Plate tectonics models explain continental drift and geological activity; the rock cycle model describes the formation and transformation of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks. Plate Tectonics | Rock Cycle

title: Claude on Models
text:
Social Sciences

Economics: Supply and demand models predict market equilibrium prices; the Solow growth model explains long-term economic growth through capital accumulation and technological progress. Supply and Demand | Solow Model
Psychology: The cognitive-behavioral model links thoughts, emotions, and behaviors; Piaget’s stages of development model children’s cognitive growth through distinct phases. Cognitive-Behavioral | Piaget’s Theory
Sociology: The structural-functional model views society as interconnected parts working toward stability; social network models map relationships and information flow between individuals. Structural Functionalism | Social Network Analysis
Political Science: The median voter theorem models electoral outcomes in democratic systems; game theory models strategic interactions between political actors. Median Voter Theorem | Game Theory
Anthropology: Cultural evolution models explain how cultural traits spread and change; kinship models represent family relationships and social organization across cultures. Cultural Evolution | Kinship

title: Claude on Models
text:
Applied Sciences

Medicine: The biopsychosocial model integrates biological, psychological, and social factors in health; epidemiological models (like SIR) predict disease spread through populations. Biopsychosocial Model | SIR Model
Engineering: Finite element models simulate stress and strain in structures; circuit models represent electrical systems using idealized components like resistors and capacitors. Finite Element Method | Circuit Theory
Computer Science: The OSI model describes network communication in seven layers; computational complexity models classify algorithms by their time and space requirements. OSI Model | Computational Complexity
Environmental Science: Climate models simulate Earth’s atmospheric and oceanic systems; ecosystem models track energy flow and nutrient cycling through trophic levels. Climate Models | Ecosystem Model

title: Claude on Models
text:
Humanities and Formal Sciences

Linguistics: Chomsky’s transformational-generative grammar models sentence structure and syntax; phonological models represent sound systems and pronunciation rules. Transformational Grammar | Phonology
Mathematics: Euclidean geometry models flat space using axioms and theorems; probability models describe random events and their likelihood. Euclidean Geometry | Probability Theory
Philosophy: The theory of forms models reality as imperfect reflections of perfect ideals; utilitarian models evaluate moral actions based on consequences and overall happiness. Theory of Forms | Utilitarianism
History: Cyclical models view history as repeating patterns; the Annales school model examines long-term social and economic structures rather than just political events. Cyclical Theory | Annales School
Education: Bloom’s taxonomy models learning objectives in hierarchical cognitive levels; constructivist models view learning as active knowledge construction by students. Bloom’s Taxonomy | Constructivism
Geography: The von Thünen model predicts agricultural land use patterns around markets; gravity models estimate interaction between places based on size and distance. Von Thünen Model | Gravity Model

title: On Models
text:
For Next Class:

Reading: Chapter 1: Open Introduction to Statistics: (On Canvas > Files > OpenIntroStatistics).

Deliverable: An In-class exercise [Assignment 2] and pending Assignment 1

title: On Models
section: Prompt: What is the Lorenz model of climate extremes?
text:
Prompt: What is the Lorenz model of climate extremes?
The Lorenz model is a simplified mathematical model used to describe atmospheric convection.1 It is one of the most famous systems in physics because it was the first to demonstrate chaotic behavior—the phenomenon where deterministic systems behave unpredictably due to extreme sensitivity to initial conditions.2
This model is responsible for the modern understanding that long-term weather forecasting is fundamentally impossible, a concept popularized as the “Butterfly Effect.”3

The Origin: A Happy Accident In 1963, MIT meteorologist Edward Lorenz was using a computer to simulate weather patterns.4 He was running a code based on twelve equations that modeled the way air moves when it is heated from below and cooled from above.5

One day, he wanted to repeat a simulation he had run previously.6 To save time, he started the run from the middle, typing in numbers from a previous printout. The printout displayed numbers to 3 decimal places (e.g., 0.506), but the computer calculated internally to 6 decimal places (e.g., 0.506127).7
Lorenz assumed this tiny difference (one part in a thousand) would have no meaningful effect. Instead, he found that the new simulation quickly diverged completely from the original, looking like a totally different weather system.8 This led him to publish his landmark paper, “Deterministic Nonperiodic Flow,” which founded the field of Chaos Theory.9

The Equations Lorenz simplified his original twelve equations down to just three coupled, non-linear ordinary differential equations.10

While they were derived from the complex Navier-Stokes equations (which describe fluid motion), Lorenz reduced them to a “toy model” representing a single 2D slice of atmosphere behaving like a convection roll (gas rising and falling in a loop). The equations are:
\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dx}{dt} &= \sigma (y - x) \\ \frac{dy}{dt} &= x (\rho - z) - y \\ \frac{dz}{dt} &= x y - \beta z \end{aligned}\]
The Variables (\(x, y, z\)) These do not represent coordinates in real space (like latitude/longitude). They represent the state of the fluid at any given moment: \(x\): The intensity of convection.11 (How fast is the convective roll spinning?)
\(y\): The horizontal temperature difference between the ascending (warm) and descending (cool) currents.12
\(z\): The vertical temperature distortion.13 (How much the temperature profile deviates from a linear decrease with height).14
The Parameters (\(\sigma, \rho, \beta\)) These are constants that determine the physical properties of the “atmosphere”:15
\(\sigma\) (Sigma): The Prandtl number (viscosity relative to thermal conductivity).16
\(\rho\) (Rho): The Rayleigh number (the temperature difference between the hot ground and the cool sky).17 This is the “control knob”—if you turn it up high enough, the system becomes chaotic.
\(\beta\) (Beta): A geometric factor related to the size of the convection roll. Lorenz found the famous chaotic behavior using the specific values: 18\(\sigma = 10\), 19\(\beta = 8/3\), and 20\(\rho = 28\).21

The Butterfly Effect & The Attractor

If you plot the values of \(x\), \(y\), and \(z\) over time in 3D space, the line traces out a shape that looks remarkably like a butterfly. This shape is known as the Lorenz Attractor.22 It has two “wings” (lobes):23
Left Wing: The fluid is rotating in one direction. Right Wing: The fluid reverses and rotates in the opposite direction. The Chaos: The system orbits one wing for a while, then suddenly switches to the other.24 There is no pattern to when it switches. You cannot predict when the flip will happen.
This visualization illustrates the Butterfly Effect: two points on the attractor that are infinitesimally close together (representing two weather systems that are almost identical) will eventually end up on opposite wings of the attractor (completely different weather).25
Summary of Significance Weather Prediction: The model proved that because we cannot measure the current state of the atmosphere with infinite precision (infinite decimal places), we cannot predict the weather beyond a certain timeframe (roughly two weeks). Deterministic Chaos: It proved that a system can be completely deterministic (follows rigid equations) but still behave randomly.26
Fractals: The “Strange Attractor” is a fractal; it has infinite detail and a fractional dimension (roughly 2.06 dimensions).27
Would you like me to generate a Python script to solve these equations so you can see the butterfly attractor evolve yourself?

title: On Models
section: Prompt: What is the double helix model of DNA?
text:
Prompt: What is the double helix model of DNA?
The double helix model is the description of the three-dimensional structure of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid).1 It depicts DNA not as a flat ladder, but as two long strands twisted around each other like a spiral staircase.2
This model was first published in 1953 and is considered one of the most significant discoveries in the history of biology because it revealed how genetic information is stored and copied.3

The Structure: A Twisted Ladder4 If you imagine a ladder twisted into a spiral, the double helix has two main parts: The Backbone (The Rails): The outside of the helix is formed by alternating sugar (deoxyribose) and phosphate molecules.5 This “sugar-phosphate backbone” provides the structural framework.

The Base Pairs (The Rungs): Inside the helix, connecting the two backbones, are pairs of nitrogenous bases.6 These bases hold the two strands together using hydrogen bonds.7

Key Rules of the Model The double helix is highly specific in how it is built. Three chemical rules are essential to its function: Complementary Base Pairing: The “rungs” are not random.8 A base on one strand always pairs with a specific partner on the other strand:9

Adenine (A) always pairs with Thymine (T).10
Cytosine (C) always pairs with Guanine (G).11
Why this matters: This means if you know the sequence of one strand (e.g., A-C-T-G), you automatically know the sequence of the other (T-G-A-C).12 This is the secret to how DNA copies itself.
Antiparallel Strands: The two strands run in opposite directions.13 Chemical direction is measured from the 14\(5'\) (five-prime) end to the 15\(3'\) (three-prime) end.16 In the double helix, one strand runs 17\(5' \to 3'\) while the other runs 18\(3' \to 5'\).19
Right-Handed Twist: In nature (specifically B-DNA, the most common form), the helix twists to the right, completing a full turn roughly every 10.5 base pairs.20

The Discovery The discovery of the double helix is a famous (and controversial) story of scientific competition: Watson & Crick: James Watson and Francis Crick are credited with proposing the model in 1953.21 They built physical models (using cardboard and metal plates) to fit the chemical pieces together.22 +1

Rosalind Franklin: Her work was crucial but often overlooked at the time.23 She was an expert in X-ray crystallography and captured Photo 51, a famous X-ray image that clearly showed the “X” pattern characteristic of a helix.24 Watson used this data (shown to him without her permission by Maurice Wilkins) to confirm the helical structure.25 +2
The Nobel Prize: In 1962, Watson, Crick, and Wilkins were awarded the Nobel Prize.26 Franklin had passed away four years earlier and was not eligible for the posthumous award, though modern science recognizes her as a co-discoverer.
Summary of Components Component Description Nucleotide
The basic building block, consisting of one sugar, one phosphate, and one base. Hydrogen Bonds Weak bonds that hold the A-T and C-G base pairs together (like a zipper). Sugar-Phosphate The structural “rails” that protect the genetic code inside.
Would you like me to explain how the Double Helix “unzips” to replicate itself?

title: On Models
text:
Prompt: What is ontology?
Ontology is, at its core, the study of what exists and how things are related.1
Depending on whether you are talking to a philosopher or a computer scientist, the definition shifts from abstract reality to practical data structures.2
Here is the breakdown of the two main perspectives: 1. In Philosophy (The Origin)3 In philosophy, ontology is the “study of being.”4 It is a branch of metaphysics that asks deep questions about the nature of reality.5
The Goal: To discover the fundamental categories of existence.6
Key Questions: What does it mean “to exist”? Do abstract ideas (like the number 7 or “justice”) exist in the same way a rock exists? Example: A philosopher might analyze if “holes” are real things, or if they are just the absence of something else. 2. In Computer Science (The Application) In computer science (specifically AI and Information Science), an ontology is a formal blueprint used to model knowledge.7 It is a specific way of organizing data so that computers can “understand” it.8
Instead of asking “what is reality,” a computational ontology declares: “For this specific system, these are the only things that exist, and here is how they connect.” The Goal: To help software share data, reason about information, and avoid confusion.9
The “Triples” Structure: Most computational ontologies are built on three main components: Classes (The Nouns): The categories of things (e.g., Patient, Doctor, Drug).10
Attributes (The Adjectives): The properties of those things (e.g., Name, Dosage, Blood Type).11
Relationships (The Verbs): How they interact (e.g., Doctor prescribes Drug). Summary Comparison Feature Philosophical Ontology Computational Ontology Focus The nature of reality. The structure of a specific domain’s data. Goal Truth and wisdom. Interoperability (systems talking to each other). Output Theories and essays. Knowledge Graphs, code (OWL/RDF), databases. Example “Is the mind separate from the body?” “A Smartphone is-a Device.”
Why is this important right now? You likely interact with ontologies every day without realizing it: Google Search: When you search for “Jaguar,” Google uses an ontology to figure out if you mean the animal, the car, or the football team based on the other words in your query. Healthcare: Ontologies allow different hospitals to share records. One system might say “Heart Attack” and another “Myocardial Infarction,” but the ontology links them as the exact same concept. Next Step Would you like me to show you a text-based example of what a simple ontology looks like for a common domain, like a Library or a Smart Home?

title: About
text:
obertwwalker.github.io 




Robert W. Walker, Ph. D.





Robert W. Walker is an Associate Professor of Quantitative Methods in the Atkinson Graduate School of Management at Willamette University
He earned a Ph. D. in political science from the University of Rochester in 2005 and has previously held teaching positions at Dartmouth College, Rice University, Texas A&M University, and Washington University in Saint Louis. His current research develops and applies semi-Markov processes to time-series, cross-section data in international relations and international/comparative political economy. He teaches courses in quantitative methods/applied statistics and microeconomic strategy and previously taught four iterations in the U. S. National Science Foundation funded Empirical Implications of Theoretical Models sequence at Washington University in Saint Louis. His work with Curt Signorino and Muhammet Bas was awarded the Miller Prize for the best article in Political Analysis in 2009.
His web presence is rww.science and his github is https://github.com/robertwwalker.


Robert’s Erdos-Bacon Number is 8.

title: A Syllabus and Models
text:
What is a model?
Our reading for next time defines models in science. This is a hard read but it is the only reading for the week.
Models in Science from the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
We will pay extra attention to sections 1, 3, and 5.2.
The class plan:

Discuss the syllabus, deliverables, and requirements
An overview of the course and mutual introductions.
A brief discussion of models to set the foundations for Thursday.

Your assignment for next time:

Do the reading.
Collect at least three questions and the answers provided by Google Gemini about references in the reading that were unfamiliar. If you did not run across at least three unfamiliar references, you need a more advanced course.

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text: Welcome to Managing with Data, Analytics, and Artificial Intelligence!

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
1. Models

Our organizing framework is the model. What is a model? Why models?

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
2. Data

What is data and how do we get some? We start by defining data and our relationship with data. We will explore practical methods of data gathering – from surveys and archives to experiments and crowd sourcing.
Have data, how is it typically organized? We will explore basic methods of organizing data for robust, sustainable use.

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
3. Deploying Data

How can managers use data? We will deploy basic tools of cross tabulation, frequency distributions, and simple plots before some statistical inference and model building.

title: Welcome To BUS 1301: Managing with AI
text:
4. Artificial Intelligence

What is artificial intelligence (AI)? We will highlight general features of how commonly deployed AI systems function and how they can solve challenges across various areas of business.

title: ChatGPT on Models
text:
ChatGPT, from OpenAI, is an extremely powerful AI tool. I will use it here to help me think about the use of models. A link to the interaction.

title: Gemini Data Analysis
text:
Gemini is powerful, soup to nuts, in analysing data. Let’s look at an example that literally deploys a model to generate a common quantity used in portfolio management in finance.






NotePrompt:



Please use publicly available sources to acquire the price of Apple common stock over the last five years and plot it as a time series. Then proceed to calculate the monthly returns for the stock and the monthly returns for the S&P 500 and provide a CAPM regression of beta. Finally, please allow me access to the data you used by exporting it to sheets

title: Gemini Data Analysis
text:
1. Regression Statistics (Monthly Returns)
Based on the monthly returns of Apple stock compared to the S&P 500:

Beta (\(\beta\)): 1.09
Alpha (\(\alpha\)): 0.17% (Monthly)
R-Squared (\(R^2\)): 0.44

title: Gemini Data Analysis
text:
2. Interpretation

Beta (1.09): AAPL has historically been about 9% more volatile than the S&P 500. A 1% rise in the market typically correlates with a 1.09% rise in AAPL.
Alpha (0.17%): On average, AAPL outperformed the risk-adjusted return predicted by the CAPM model by 0.17% per month.
R-Squared (0.44): Approximately 44% of Apple’s price movement can be explained by the movement of the S&P 500.

title: Gemini Data Analysis
text:
3. Plots Generated

Time Series: A line chart showing AAPL price rising from ~$128 (Jan 2021) to ~$259 (Jan 2026).
Regression: A scatter plot of SP500_Return (x-axis) vs AAPL_Return (y-axis) with a regression line of slope 1.09.



How’s that done?
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from scipy import stats
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Data from Source 1.3 (AAPL)
aapl_text = """
Jan 2026 | 259.89
Dec 2025 | 272.21
Nov 2025 | 278.85
Oct 2025 | 270.11
Sep 2025 | 254.38
Aug 2025 | 231.92
Jul 2025 | 207.13
Jun 2025 | 204.74
May 2025 | 200.43
Apr 2025 | 211.78
Mar 2025 | 221.37
Feb 2025 | 241.02
Jan 2025 | 234.94
Dec 2024 | 249.29
Nov 2024 | 236.26
Oct 2024 | 224.65
Sep 2024 | 231.70
Aug 2024 | 227.72
Jul 2024 | 220.58
Jun 2024 | 209.20
May 2024 | 190.95
Apr 2024 | 168.95
Mar 2024 | 170.09
Feb 2024 | 179.29
Jan 2024 | 182.68
Dec 2023 | 190.73
Nov 2023 | 188.17
Oct 2023 | 168.95
Sep 2023 | 169.38
Aug 2023 | 185.87
Jul 2023 | 194.09
Jun 2023 | 191.64
May 2023 | 175.12
Apr 2023 | 167.41
Mar 2023 | 162.70
Feb 2023 | 145.44
Jan 2023 | 142.15
Dec 2022 | 128
Nov 2022 | 145.83
Oct 2022 | 150.81
Sep 2022 | 135.92
Aug 2022 | 154.63
Jul 2022 | 159.61
Jun 2022 | 134.28
May 2022 | 146.18
Apr 2022 | 154.61
Mar 2022: 171.24
Feb 2022: 161.93
Jan 2022: 171.19
Dec 2021: 173.92
Nov 2021: 161.90
Oct 2021: 146.51
Sep 2021: 138.39
Aug 2021: 148.49
Jul 2021: 142.44
Jun 2021: 133.75
May 2021: 121.69
Apr 2021: 128.16
Mar 2021: 119.08
Feb 2021: 118.22
Jan 2021: 128.46
"""

# Data from Source 2.3 (S&P 500)
sp500_text = """
2026-01-09 | 6966.28
2025-12-31 | 6845.50
2025-11-28 | 6849.09
2025-10-31 | 6840.20
2025-09-30 | 6688.46
2025-08-29 | 6460.26
2025-07-31 | 6339.39
2025-06-30 | 6204.95
2025-05-30 | 5911.69
2025-04-30 | 5569.06
2025-03-31 | 5611.85
2025-02-28 | 5954.50
2025-01-31 | 6040.53
2024-12-31 | 5881.63
2024-11-29 | 6032.38
2024-10-31 | 5705.45
2024-09-30 | 5762.48
2024-08-30 | 5648.40
2024-07-31 | 5522.30
2024-06-28 | 5460.48
2024-05-31 | 5277.51
2024-04-30 | 5035.69
2024-03-28 | 5254.35
2024-02-29 | 5096.27
2024-01-31 | 4845.65
2023-12-29 | 4769.83
2023-11-30 | 4567.80
2023-10-31 | 4193.80
2023-09-29 | 4288.05
2023-08-31 | 4507.66
2023-07-31 | 4588.96
2023-06-30 | 4450.38
2023-05-31 | 4179.83
2023-04-28 | 4169.48
2023-03-31 | 4109.31
2023-02-28 | 3970.15
2023-01-31 | 4076.60
2022-12-31 | 3839.50
2022-11-30 | 4080.11
2022-10-31 | 3871.98
2022-09-30 | 3585.62
2022-08-31 | 3955.00
2022-07-29 | 4130.29
2022-06-30 | 3785.38
2022-05-31 | 4132.15
2022-04-29 | 4131.93
2022-03-31 | 4530.41
2022-02-28 | 4373.94
2022-01-31 | 4515.55
2021-12-31 | 4766.18
2021-11-30 | 4567.00
2021-10-29 | 4605.38
2021-09-30 | 4307.54
2021-08-31 | 4522.68
2021-07-30 | 4395.26
2021-06-30 | 4297.50
2021-05-28 | 4204.11
2021-04-30 | 4181.17
2021-03-31 | 3972.89
2021-02-26 | 3811.15
2021-01-29 | 3714.24
"""

# Processing AAPL
aapl_data = []
for line in aapl_text.strip().split('\n'):
    parts = line.replace(':', '|').split('|')
    if len(parts) >= 2:
        date_str = parts[0].strip()
        price_str = parts[1].strip()
        aapl_data.append({'Date': date_str, 'AAPL': float(price_str)})

df_aapl = pd.DataFrame(aapl_data)
# Convert Date to datetime. "Jan 2026" needs format.
df_aapl['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_aapl['Date'], format='%b %Y') + pd.offsets.MonthEnd(0) # Align to month end

# Processing S&P 500
sp500_data = []
for line in sp500_text.strip().split('\n'):
    parts = line.split('|')
    if len(parts) >= 2:
        date_str = parts[0].strip()
        price_str = parts[1].strip().replace(',', '')
        sp500_data.append({'Date': date_str, 'SP500': float(price_str)})

df_sp500 = pd.DataFrame(sp500_data)
df_sp500['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_sp500['Date']) + pd.offsets.MonthEnd(0)

# Merge
df_merged = pd.merge(df_aapl, df_sp500, on='Date', how='inner')
df_merged = df_merged.sort_values('Date')

# Calculate Monthly Returns
df_merged['AAPL_Return'] = df_merged['AAPL'].pct_change()
df_merged['SP500_Return'] = df_merged['SP500'].pct_change()

# Drop NaN (first row)
df_returns = df_merged.dropna()

# CAPM Regression
# y = AAPL_Return, x = SP500_Return
slope, intercept, r_value, p_value, std_err = stats.linregress(df_returns['SP500_Return'], df_returns['AAPL_Return'])

print(f"Beta: {slope}")
print(f"Alpha: {intercept}")
print(f"R-squared: {r_value**2}")

# Plotting AAPL Price
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(df_merged['Date'], df_merged['AAPL'], label='AAPL Price')
plt.title('Apple (AAPL) Stock Price - Last 5 Years')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('Price ($)')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.savefig('aapl_price_history.png')

# Plotting Returns Relationship
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
plt.scatter(df_returns['SP500_Return'], df_returns['AAPL_Return'], alpha=0.5)
plt.plot(df_returns['SP500_Return'], intercept + slope * df_returns['SP500_Return'], 'r', label=f'Fit: y={slope:.2f}x + {intercept:.4f}')
plt.title('Monthly Returns: AAPL vs S&P 500')
plt.xlabel('S&P 500 Monthly Return')
plt.ylabel('AAPL Monthly Return')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.savefig('capm_regression.png')

# Export to CSV
df_merged.to_csv('aapl_sp500_data.csv', index=False)


Beta: 1.091504481063609
Alpha: 0.001743016912168079
R-squared: 0.4448837540235066
















Cute.
And it matches.



Yahoo! Finance

title: Formatting a Gemini Response
text: Gemini is powerful, and a few tidbits help a great deal. I use markdown formatting for text inputs and Gemini is well versed in this. My prompts now use please format responses in markdown and include links to the noted sources.

title: Formatting a Gemini Response
text:
Commentary
The content is excellent. The formatting is not. And the Docs version is no better.



Gemini output


The notes have no content. It looks fine but it is not complete. Let me prompt again and see if I can get something to work with.

title: GrokAI on Models
text:
TL;DR
Grok AI, from Elon Musk’s xAI, is a powerful AI tool. I will use it here to help me think about the use of models. A link to the interaction.



Grok Interactions

how are models used in academic disciplines? give an example or two of common models in at least 20 academic disciplines in a formatted table with a linked reference for each model that provides more extensive detail and a column that includes whether the model is predictive or explanatory. the response should be functional markdown code


Grok did not really comply. Ever.
